summary: inflammation during microbial infections, autoimmunity, or spinal cord injury is associated with recruitment of various B cell subsets. however, humoral responses persist during chronic CNS diseases such as subacute sclerosing panencephalitis and multiple sclerosis (6–8). factor of the tumor necrosis factor family (TNF) and a proliferation-inducing ligand (APRIL) are also upregulated during virus- or autoantigen-induced CNS inflammation. there is no evidence for ectopic lymphoid follicles during Sindbis virus infection. infected mice exhibit impaired humoral responses in the CNS. naive/early-activated B cells migrate indiscriminately to sites of acute inflammation as bystanders but are replaced by more differentiated B cells derived from peripheral germinal centers. intracranial injection of sterile phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) does not elicit an increase in the number of infiltrating CD45hi cells by flow cytometry 5 days later compared to naive mice. titers within the brain and spinal cord were determined by a plaque assay using the murine delayed brain tumor astrocytoma (DBT) cell line. optimum densities were read at 450 nm on a SpectraMax Mz microplate reader. data are expressed as arbitrary units/mg tissue, where 1 arbitrary unit equals an absorbance of 0.1. background levels from naive mice were subtracted. mononuclear cells were recovered from a percoll step gradient. single-cell suspensions from cervical lymph nodes were prepared. cells were staining with MAbs specific for CD19 (MAb 1D3), CD45 (30-F11), CD138 (281-2), IgD (11-26), IgG2a/b (R2-40) cells were washed with RPMI supplemented with 25 mM HEPES. mononuclear cells were recovered from the 30%–70% interface of a Percoll gradient. a minimum of 1 105 cells were collected per pooled sample and frozen in 400 l TRIzol. quantitative real-time PCR was performed by using 40 ng of cDNA and SYBR green master mix.
